Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.2.Ej.588 - Western Amazon Lowland Humid Forest VU'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.2.Ej.588 - Western Amazon Lowland Humid Forest VU'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.2.Ej.588 - Western Amazon Lowland Humid Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.2.Ej Amazonian Lowland Humid Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Biotic-processes.Summary: Bosques altos, multiestratificados con abundantes lianas y epifitas, es considerado de los bosques mas diversos en especies de arboles. Las familias que mas se encuentran son Fabaceae, Myristicaceae, Bombacaceae, Meliaceae, Vochysiaceae, Lauraceae, Rubiaceae, and Palmae.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq. Siempreverde humedo. Se presentan en la cuenca Amazonica al sur de Colombia, todo el ecuador, norte de el rio Ucayali en Perú y oeste del rio Japura en Brasil. Crecen en diferentes geomorfologias: riberas, terrazas superiores, penillanuras, colinas bajas.
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Eastern Cordillera real montane forests'
Global 200 ecoregion 'Amazon River and Flooded Forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.A.2.Ej.588 - Western Amazon Lowland Humid Forest' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for VU was reached for criterion.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A3.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Assessment-unit.name: Bolivia

Ecosystem-subset.name: National: Bolivia
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Country-level assessment of '1.A.2.Ej.588 - Western Amazon Lowland Humid Forest' macrogroup in Bolivia.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for CR was reached for criteria.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A1 could be in the range of LC -- NT.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of predicted future change in tree cover reached the threshold for CR for subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A3.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Assessment-unit.name: Brazil

Ecosystem-subset.name: National: Brazil
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Country-level assessment of '1.A.2.Ej.588 - Western Amazon Lowland Humid Forest' macrogroup in Brazil.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: None of the evaluated indicators reached the thresholds for Vulnerable for any criteria, and is considered Least Concern. Uncertainty in the indicators suggests that the overall category can be in the range os LC -- NT.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A3.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A3.

Criterion.name: E

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for EN was reached for criterion. Uncertainty in the indicators suggests that the overall category can be in the range os VU -- EN.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.2.Ej.589 - Western Amazon Subandean Humid Forest VU'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.2.Ej.589 - Western Amazon Subandean Humid Forest VU'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.2.Ej.589 - Western Amazon Subandean Humid Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.2.Ej Amazonian Lowland Humid Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Biotic-processes.Summary: Bosques altos, multiestratificado. La composicion es tipica de bosques amazonicos occidentales pero con algunos elementos andinos.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq. Siempreverde humedo. Se halla en las colinas sub-andinas de la cuenca del amazonas occidental de la Sierra de la Macarena en Colombia hasta el centro de Perú. Crece entre los 500-1300 msnm.
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Eastern Cordillera real montane forests'
Global 200 ecoregion 'Amazon River and Flooded Forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: Ecuador

Ecosystem-subset.name: National: Ecuador
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Country-level assessment of '1.A.2.Ej.589 - Western Amazon Subandean Humid Forest' macrogroup in Ecuador.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for VU was reached for criterion.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A1 could be in the range of LC -- VU.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was near to the threshold for Vulnerable. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened under subcriterion A2b. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A2b could be in the range of VU -- LC.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A3.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was near to the threshold for Vulnerable. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened under subcriterion A1. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A1 could be in the range of LC -- VU.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of predicted future change in tree cover reached the threshold for VU for subcriterion A2b. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A2b could be in the range of EN -- VU.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was near to the threshold for Vulnerable. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened under subcriterion A3. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A3 could be in the range of LC -- VU.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.2.Ej.590 - Southwestern Amazon Lowland Humid Forest VU'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.2.Ej.590 - Southwestern Amazon Lowland Humid Forest VU'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.2.Ej.590 - Southwestern Amazon Lowland Humid Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.2.Ej Amazonian Lowland Humid Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Abiotic-environment.Summary: Humedo con estacionalidad Presenta topografia irregular, llanuras onduladas y colinas altas

Biotic-processes.Summary: Existen grandes extensiones dominadas por el bambu (Guadua)

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq. Siempreverde humedo. Se hallan en el este y sur del rio Ucayali en Perú, Madre de Dios y en la cuenca baja de Perú y Bolivia. Tambien se encuentra en Jarua y Yavarí en Brasil.
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Eastern Cordillera real montane forests'
Global 200 ecoregion 'Amazon River and Flooded Forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.A.2.Ej.590 - Southwestern Amazon Lowland Humid Forest' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for VU was reached for criterion.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A3.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.2.Ej.591 - Southwestern Amazon Subandean Humid Forest EN (VU -- EN)'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.2.Ej.591 - Southwestern Amazon Subandean Humid Forest EN (VU -- EN)'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.2.Ej.591 - Southwestern Amazon Subandean Humid Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.2.Ej Amazonian Lowland Humid Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Abiotic-environment.Summary: Suelos pobres y bien drenados con textura franco arcillosa

Biotic-processes.Summary: La composicion floristica es predominantemente amazonica se encuentran algunos elementos andinos.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq. Siempreverde humedo 2. Bsq. Siempreverdes hiper-humedos Se encuentra en las colinas sub-andinas de la cuenca del Amazonas al suroeste de Perú y Bolivia. Esta presente entre los 500-1300 msnm
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Eastern Cordillera real montane forests'
Global 200 ecoregion 'Amazon River and Flooded Forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.A.2.Ej.591 - Southwestern Amazon Subandean Humid Forest' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for EN was reached for criterion. Uncertainty in the indicators suggests that the overall category can be in the range os VU -- EN.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of predicted future change in tree cover reached the threshold for VU for subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A3.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.2.Ej.592 - Northern Amazon Humid Forest NT (LC -- NT)'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.2.Ej.592 - Northern Amazon Humid Forest NT (LC -- NT)'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.2.Ej.592 - Northern Amazon Humid Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.2.Ej Amazonian Lowland Humid Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Biotic-processes.Summary: Bosques altos y densos en los interfluvios y altos margenes de los rios.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq. Siempreverde humedo 2. Bsq. Semi-siempreverdes Se presenta en las llanuras sedimentarias al noreste del Amazonas. En Brasil se distribuyen en la cuenca de los rios Japurá y Negro limitando con los bosques de Guayana de arenas blancas en Venezuela, llegando a la zona transicional norte de bosques estacionales. En Colombia se encuentrabn la norte del rio Caqueta hasta el Guaviare y al este de las cuencas del Apaporis y Vaupés.
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Guianan piedmont and lowland moist forests'
Global 200 ecoregion 'Amazon River and Flooded Forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.A.2.Ej.592 - Northern Amazon Humid Forest' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: None of the evaluated indicators reached the thresholds for Vulnerable for any criteria, but it almost reached the threshold for criterion and could become Vulnerable soon. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened. Uncertainty in the indicators suggests that the overall category can be in the range os LC -- NT.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A3.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.2.Ej.593 - Central Amazon Humid Forest VU'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.2.Ej.593 - Central Amazon Humid Forest VU'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.2.Ej.593 - Central Amazon Humid Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.2.Ej Amazonian Lowland Humid Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Biotic-processes.Summary: Bosque alto y multi-estratificado, rico en epifitas y lianas.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq. Siempreverde humedo. Se hallan en la cuenca central y baja del Amazonas al este de Manaos, asi como en los interfluvios a lo largo del afluente principal y hacia la región Uatuma Trombetas al norte.
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: Global 200 ecoregion 'Amazon River and Flooded Forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.
